S1.T1.caption: Table 1: Utility guarantee of (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta) differential privacy (upper part) and rate of communication round needed to achieve ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon accuracy (lower part) for μ𝜇\mu strongly-convex and non-convex optimization problems. ‡‡\ddagger denotes that logarithmic factors are ignored here. See S7 for more details. ††\dagger denotes that no client subsampling is used. In full participation scenarios, τ=1𝜏1\tau=1 and log⁡(S)=log⁡(N)𝑆𝑁\log(S)=\log(N). ∗∗\ast after DP-Fed-LS further denotes the specific setting of IID (G=0)𝐺0(G=0) with K≫1much-greater-than𝐾1K\gg 1. For centralized settings [8, 54, 53], N𝑁N denotes the number of data points, while in federated learning, N𝑁N denotes the number of clients. DP-SRM [55] is a distributed setting where N𝑁N and n~~𝑛\tilde{n} denote the number of clients and number of samples owned by each client, respectively. They consider data-level DP while we consider user-level DP.
references: The proof sketch of Theorem 3 can be found in Section C in Appendix. In this theorem, dominant errors are introduced by the variance of stochastic gradients (ς2​(σ)/Ksuperscript𝜍2𝜎𝐾\varsigma^{2}(\sigma)/K), heterogeneity of Non-IID data ((1−τ)​G21𝜏superscript𝐺2(1-\tau)G^{2}) and DP (dσsubscript𝑑𝜎d_{\sigma} and d~σsubscript~𝑑𝜎\tilde{d}_{\sigma}), in comparison to the initial error. Among the three dominant errors, the variance term ς2​(σ)/Ksuperscript𝜍2𝜎𝐾\varsigma^{2}(\sigma)/K will diminish while the number of local iteration K𝐾K grows large enough (K≫1much-greater-than𝐾1K\gg 1). What’s more, the heterogeneity term (1−τ)​G21𝜏superscript𝐺2(1-\tau)G^{2} will be reduced if subsampling ratio τ𝜏\tau is high. Particularly, in IID (G=0𝐺0G=0) or full-device participation (τ=1)𝜏1(\tau=1) setting, this term will vanish. Therefore the error term introduced by DP, of effective dimensionality dσsubscript𝑑𝜎d_{\sigma} or d~σsubscript~𝑑𝜎\tilde{d}_{\sigma}, dominates the variance and heterogeneity terms in these scenarios, whose rates in Theorem 3 matches the optimal ones of ERM via SGD with differential privacy in centralized setting [53, 54], as shown in the upper part of Table 1. In Table 1, the term log⁡(S)𝑆\log(S) of DP-Fed-LS comes from the numerator of learning rate η~~𝜂\tilde{\eta} in Theorem 4 in Appendix, implicitly involved in 𝒪~~𝒪\tilde{\mathcal{O}}.

In Table 1, for [30], the log⁡(T)𝑇\log(T) term in denominators are ignored. For the communication complexity with strongly-convex condition for [29] and DP-Fed-LS, the log⁡S𝑆\log{S} and log⁡K𝐾\log{K} terms in numerator are ignored.

references: Improved test accuracy under the same privacy budget. From Table 2, we notice that DP-Fed-LS outperforms DP-Fed in almost all settings. In particular, when ε𝜀\varepsilon is small, the improvement of DP-Fed-LS is remarkably large. We show the training curves in Figure 2, where we find that DP-Fed-LS converges slower than DP-Fed in both subsampling scenarios. However, DP-Fed-LS will generalize better than DP-Fed at the later stage of training. Other training curves are deferred to the Section S5 in supplementary material.

Improved test accuracy under the same privacy budget. Table 3
shows that DP-Fed-LS yields higher accuracy than DP-Fed with both subsampling mechanisms and different DP guarantees. We show training curves in Figure 3, which are similar to the ones of the logistic regression. Again, training curves of DP-Fed-LS converge slower than that of DP-Fed, especially when uniform subsampling is used. However, DP-Fed-LS generalizes better than DP-Fed at the later stage.

In Table 4, we show the results of another two adaptive denoising estimators: the James-Stein estimator (JS) and the soft-thresholding estimator (TH), which have been shown to be useful for high dimensional parameter estimation and number release [5], comparing with other denoising estimators [6, 24, 57, 10]. As mentioned in [5], thanks to the fact that we know the parameter ν𝜈\nu exactly, both JS and TH estimators are completely free of tuning parameters. However, as we can see in Table 4, neither of these two estimators performs well in our scenario, compared with Laplacian smoothing in Table 3, indicating that high dimensional sparsity assumption [5] does not hold here on federated average of gradients.

references: In Table 4, we show the results of another two adaptive denoising estimators: the James-Stein estimator (JS) and the soft-thresholding estimator (TH), which have been shown to be useful for high dimensional parameter estimation and number release [5], comparing with other denoising estimators [6, 24, 57, 10]. As mentioned in [5], thanks to the fact that we know the parameter ν𝜈\nu exactly, both JS and TH estimators are completely free of tuning parameters. However, as we can see in Table 4, neither of these two estimators performs well in our scenario, compared with Laplacian smoothing in Table 3, indicating that high dimensional sparsity assumption [5] does not hold here on federated average of gradients.

Stability under large noise, learning rate and different orders of parameter flattening. In Figure 4, we show the training curves where relatively large noise multipliers z𝑧z are applied with Poisson subsampling and different local learning rates ηlsubscript𝜂𝑙\eta_{l}. Here our CNNs are trained for one run from scratch. When the noise levels are large, the training curves fluctuate a lot.
In these extreme cases, DP-Fed-LS outperforms DP-Fed by a large margin. For example, when z=3𝑧3z=3 and ηl=0.05subscript𝜂𝑙0.05\eta_{l}=0.05, validation accuracy of DP-Fed starts to drop at the 150th epoch while DP-Fed-LS can still converge. When the learning rate increase to 0.1250.1250.125, validation accuracy of DP-Fed drops below 0.2 after the 25th epoch while DP-Fed-LS approaches 0.7 at the end. Overall speaking, DP-Fed-LS is more stable against large noise levels and the change of local learning rate than DP-Fed. What’s more, from Table 5, we notice that DP-Fed-LS is insensitive to the order of parameter flattening and consistently performs better than DP-Fed.

references: Improved test accuracy under the same privacy budget. The test accuracy in Table 6 are comparable to the one in [13]. We can also conclude that DP-Fed-LS provides better utility than DP-Fed. The training curves are plotted in Figure 5. Generally speaking, the training curves in Non-IID setting suffer from larger fluctuation than the ones in IID setting above. And the curves of DP-Fed-LS are smoother than DP-Fed, which further shows the potential of DP-Fed-LS in real-world applications.
